item.title: My Year 2017
item.description:
“Habit is habit, and not to be flung out of the window by any man, but coaxed down-stairs one step at a time.” ‚Äï Mark Twain

When sitting comfortably in front of the chimney and holding a cup of warm Gl√ºhwein, along with the Christmas holiday melody, we all know by heart that 2018 is almost here.

At this moment, I feel warm, relax and a bit drunk. It’s the perfect timing for me to recap my year 2017. If considering my year 2016 as “beginning”, I would say that my year 2017 is a year of “iterating”: building the habit of learning, step by step; keeping learning, little by little.

Keep reading

Surprisingly, I managed to finish only 1 book this year:

  • Gene Kim: The DevOps Handbook. Here is my humble book review.

2 interesting books I started to read and I’m still reading:

  • Katrina Clokie: A Practical Guide to Testing in DevOps
  • Gojko Adzic: Humans vs Computers

To be honest, I didn’t organize my time quite well focusing on reading books. However, I spent my most of time reading short articles, medium posts and tech news… As the result, I read 3,657,021 words, which is 1.75x more than last year:

Nice yearly review from @Pocket
I'll keep reading and learning. pic.twitter.com/fr1NYNUmAp

— ùô†ùôöùô´ùôûùô£ . (@KevCui) December 9, 2017

Keep blogging

20 blog posts (including this one) are written in 2017. Among them:

  • 9 posts about software testing and tester,
  • 5 posts about how to set up a (better) blog site
  • 1 book review
  • 5 others for others, like Firefox, Colemak…

I like blogging even no one is reading. Next year, I plan to blog small posts more frequently.

Keep listening

This year, I did listen to podcasts a lot: software testing, IoT, science, history… My favorite must-listen software testing podcasts are:

  • Alan Pages & Brent Jensen: AB Testing
  • Keith Klain: Quality Remarks
  • Neil Studd: Testers’ Island

Keep TestBash-in

Like other awesome testers, undoubtedly, I see Ministry of Testing as an active community to share testing knowledge. This year, I got the chance to be a part of TestBash, which was the first time hosted in Germany. With plenty of passionate testers, I enjoyed every minute of TestBash. I’m looking forward to the next meet.

My 1st #testbash experience was really amazing! Great talks, awesome testers, nice location, decent food... See u next time üòòüëä #oktobertest

— ùô†ùôöùô´ùôûùô£ . (@KevCui) October 6, 2017

As I said in my 2016 yearly review, “For the next year, I don’t expect a big change coming, but maybe some small changes. What I know is that my journey will continue, step by step.”, it will still stay true for the next year.

Happy Holiday & Happy New Year!

item.title: My Year 2k16
item.description:
“A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.” – Lao Tzu

There is a tradition in Japan since 1995: Every year, one character will be chosen as kanji of the year at Kiyomizu Temple, which represents the events of the entire year.

So I choose the character of my year 2016 is Shi

It means: to start, beginning.

Begin to connect

01 Jan 2016: A new habit

Actually it’s easy for me to build this habit. I have too much time during my daily commute. Why not use this time for reading articles I bookmarked? I’m quite happy that I keep reading every day to charge my brain. Things are learned from reading which inspires me to think more, to go deeper into the question why behind what.

A small fun fact: In 2016, I read 2,089,596 words in Pocket, which is like reading 44 books. What a surprise I didn’t expect!

Also, I managed to finish reading:

  • Bug Advocacy - Cem Kaner

  • How Google Tests Software - James A. Whittaker

  • Mr. Fails - Andy Glover

  • The Linux Command Line - William Shotts

  • The Dream Team Nightmare - Portia Tung

  • The Art of Agile Development - James Shore

And I finished rereading:

  • Hands-on Mobile App Testing - Daniel Knott

But I left some books which are not finished yet:

  • Eat That Frog - Brian Tracy

  • Think, Fast and Slow - Daniel Kahneman

22 May 2016: A new tweet

After abandoned Twitter account 6 years ago, I come back to Twitter over again.

With the main focus on software testing, I followed tons of awesome people, read lots of great posts and participated some interesting challenges as well. I feel so happy to see passionate testers tweeting around with new interesting ideas and concepts. Also, I saw many doubts and misunderstanding of QA, tester and testing…

Good or bad are two sides of the same coin. The point of view to an alive thing cannot be perfectly right or absolutely wrong. I started to question “What is quality?”, “What is my job as tester and QA?”, “What is testing?” and “What is wrong with them?”… As far as I can see, software testing itself is evolving, for a new era.

07 Aug 2016: The first repository

I started to program something for fun. Actually, what I did isn’t a big deal at all: some CLI geek-weird scripts and wrappers of some unpopular API… But the most important thing is that I had a lot of fun. I enjoy the time when I do programming! Do I test my code? Nope, not now XD

18 Nov 2016: A new blog

A new blog üéâ Yes, another one! What’s different? Totally different, this time it’s a cooler way to blog. I promise that I will continue to keep recording crazy things happen in my journey.

Begin to refine

What is quality?

I started to change my understanding of the definition of quality, from “The traditional software quality model identifies 6 main quality characteristics: ….”[1] to “Quality is value to some person.”[2]

What is my job?

My job title is QA Engineer, as known as, Quality Assurance Engineer.

How am I able to make quality assured? Not really.

“We don‚Äôt own quality. We’re helping the people who are responsible for quality and the things that influence it.”[3]

I see myself as a Quality Assistance[4]

My role: Quality Control -> Quality Assurance -> Quality Assistance
Me: Focus product -> Focus process -> Focus team motivation on testing

— @KevCui November 4, 2016

What is testing?

“Checking Is Confirmation. Testing Is Exploration and Learning.”[5]

I see testing is a way to explore unknown of the product and to provide information about the awareness of risks.

Nice metaphor! I do my best to provide correct relative info to who need know risks. Based on info, not me, they take care of their sleep... https://t.co/Vuofazss3G

— @KevCui November 28, 2016

Begin to be “Crazy”

“Crazy” is being out of the ordinary. It’s a courage to have breakthrough thinking. I knew that some experiments sound “crazy” but I really did them:

Don’t open new bug ticket immediately until must-have

When I have some findings, I’d like to check with other team members first, instead of logging it into bug tracking tool. Why? Because there is no value added to log a bug, fix it does. If its severity is low, regarding effort and outcome, it won’t be fixed; If its severity is high, we should eliminate it immediately.[6]

Another good thing without a bug ticket: I have to talk to developers and show them how the issue looks like. Then we could start to discuss what’s the correct behavior from the programming perspective and from the user perspective. Then we go for a fix and test the fix together. For me, until now it’s the most efficient way to fix bugs.

Remove manual regression tests because I’m shifted-left[7]

No manual regression tests don’t mean not verify bug fix at all. The idea is old “Do testing as early as possible.” Instead of checking fix after developer says “done”, all manual tests should be done earlier before integration. It makes the feedback circle smaller. Let’s say “done” together.

Make team testing great with lots of fun

I say goodbye to the boring team testing. It’s not my style to organize a traditional team testing. I urge to make it funny.

1/2 Testing should be full of fun, like a treasure hunting, an Easter egg search, a Geocache... a game to enjoy to have fun, not to win it

2/2 I'd like to make a Team Testing:
New features over Whole product
User nature act over Planned step
Motivation driven over Result driven

— @KevCui November 4, 2016

Ignore low usage OS version in order to gain precious time

I removed a target OS version in scope in test plan because of its user coverage is really low. It turned to be a really big mistake. üò∂

What I learnt:
1. Never ignore an OS if it's still in scope
2. Still perform some tests on low coverage OS to at least check main functions

— @KevCui November 28, 2016

Beginning of a New Year

For the next year, I don’t expect a big change coming, but maybe some small changes. What I know is that my journey will continue, step by step.

I’ll Fail friendly, Learn fast and Stay strong!
